description:
Chlamydia poikilotherma is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Chlamydia. As the name "poikilotherma" suggests, this species is known to be poikilothermic, meaning that its body temperature varies with the temperature of its environment.

Chlamydia poikilotherma is an obligate intracellular parasite, meaning that it can only replicate and survive within the cells of a host organism. It is known to infect various species of fish and amphibians, causing a range of diseases and developmental abnormalities.

The bacterial cells of Chlamydia poikilotherma have a characteristic biphasic life cycle, alternating between an infectious elementary body and a replicative reticulate body. This unique life cycle allows the bacteria to persist within the host cells and evade the host's immune response.

Chlamydia poikilotherma is considered an important pathogen in the aquaculture industry, as it can cause significant economic losses due to its impact on the health and productivity of farmed fish and amphibians. Research on this species continues to explore its biology, epidemiology, and potential treatment strategies to mitigate its effects on aquatic ecosystems and aquaculture operations.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Chlamydia poikilotherma
